we.sentence: We had to go quite a bit farther than usual before we could surround a  little bunch of antelope, and as I was helping drive them, I saw a fine  red deer a couple of hundred yards behind me.
We all come from there, he said.
We will take a cave high up.
We must find a cave.
We ran as fast as we could around the lower end of the  harbor, scrambled up the cliffs and at last stood upon their summit in  full view of the lake.
We all looked up as the noise approached apparently just  above us, and a moment later there followed a terrific explosion which  hurled us to the ground.
We descended to the compound, and I walked with Lys to the  door of her quarters.

We went up the coast some ten or twelve miles in the U33, tying up to  shore near the mouth of a small stream which emptied great volumes of  crude oil into the seaI find it difficult to call this great lake by  any other name.
We are all elated to the seventh heaven of bliss.
We have  been living upon the fat of the land, Ahm having shown us the edible  fruits, tubers and herbs, and twice a week we go out after fresh meat.

We changed our plans a trifle when it came to building the palisade,  for we found a rotted cliff near by where we could get all the flat  buildingstone we needed, and so we constructed a stone wall entirely  around the buildings.

We saw nothing of the wild men of the previous day, and only once were  we menaced by any of the strange denizens of Caprona, when some  frightful nightmare of the sky swooped down upon us, only to be driven  off by a fusillade of bullets.
We decided to take  him with us to camp, and by means of belts we managed to secure his  hands behind his back and place a leash around his neck before he  regained consciousness.
We were about a quarter of a mile from the rest of our party, and in  full sight of them as they lay in the tall grass watching us.
We got within a hundred yards of  the deer when he suddenly raised his antlered head and pricked up his  great ears.
We followed the stream upward through a beautiful country  for about five miles, and then came upon its source in a little  boulderstrewn clearing.
We ran along beside them for a matter of ten miles, arriving off a  broad cleft which led into what appeared to be another lake.
We found the lake deep and the bottom rocky and  steeply shelving toward the center, and once when I moved straight out  from shore to take other soundings we could find no bottom whatsoever.
We had an easy time getting  awayas we learned later, because the saurians do not commence to feed  until late in the morning.
We also dipped  up some of the river water and found it, though quite warm, a little  sweeter than before.
We proceeded up the river for some forty miles before darkness overtook  us.
We looked in the direction he pointed and saw  a long, glossy neck surmounted by a small head rising above the surface  of the river.

We were in the middle of a broad and now sluggish river the banks of  which were lined by giant, arboraceous ferns, raising their mighty  fronds fifty, one hundred, two hundred feet into the quiet air.
We had advanced a hundred yards, perhaps, when our first  danger confronted us.
We submerged very slowly and without  headway more than sufficient to keep her nose in the right direction,  and as we went down, I saw outlined ahead of us the black opening in  the great cliff.
We have the  means for navigating a subterranean river.
We havent one chance for life in a  hundred thousand if we dont find food and water upon Caprona.

We were already rather close in; but I ordered the U33s prow turned  inshore and we crept slowly along, constantly dipping up the water and  tasting it to assure ourselves that we didnt get outside the  freshwater current.
We cant afford to give up heart now, when we need heart most.
We were now thirstier than ever.
We will find it, Bradley, for we must find it.
We took our bearings with our crude and inaccurate instruments; we  searched the chart; we cudgeled our brains; and at last it was Bradley  who suggested a solution.
We opened a new tank.
We thought he was crazy; but he wasnt, for that afternoon we sighted a  great berg south of us, and wed been running north, we thought, for  days.
We reckoned, or rather guessed, that we were somewhere off  the coast of Peru.
We were all asleep.
We were sailing due west.
We moved in quite close to her.
We were all pretty well done up  and looked forward to the time when we could go on deck and fill our  lungs with fresh air.
We will meet even a worse reception if we  go nosing around a British portmines, nets and all of it.
We hoisted the Union Jack and remained on deck, asking Bradley to go  below and assign to each member of the crew his duty, placing one  Englishman with a pistol beside each German.
We were within fifty feet of them when they awakened to the intentional  menace of our maneuver.
We were thirsty, hungry, uncomfortable, and cold.
We were caught in the suction  only enough to be drawn backward a few yards, neither of us being  carried beneath the surface.

We were  thrown to the decks, bruised and stunned, and then above the ship,  carrying with it fragments of steel and wood and dismembered human  bodies, rose a column of water hundreds of feet into the air.
We were entirely  defenseless; yet without warning, we were being torpedoed.
We have a story of a flight and a descent by ropes which precluded the  production of larger specimens.
We turned and  plunged into the cave which led to home.
We are  through!
We turned into it to find that we  were in a much larger passage than before.
We  hurried eagerly along it until, with a deep groan of bitter  disappointment, we were brought to a halt.
We have descended in safety, though in a most unexpected fashion, and  all is well with us.
We have satisfied ourselves that we cannot climb down and that  there is no tunnel.
We now stood  amazed at the sight, for their blotched and warty skins were of a  curious fishlike iridescence, and the sunlight struck them with an  evervarying rainbow bloom as they moved.
We had both seized  our magazine rifles and ran out to see what the danger could be.
We kept our independence, therefore,  and had our weapons ready for any emergency, while preserving the most  friendly relations.
We had returned across the plateau with our allies two days after the  battle, and made our camp at the foot of their cliffs.
We are held here with no clear means of making our escape, and  bitterly we chafe against it.
We have  had adventures enough and they are neither suitable to our character or  our position.
We had not long to wait for our enemy.
We are blessed, my dear  Challenger, above all zoologists since the world began!

We had, it is true, been only a week or so upon the top of  the plateau, but all our spare clothing was in our camp below, and the  one week had been a severe one upon us all, though least to me who had  not to endure the handling of the apemen.
We saw no sign of pursuit, however, and soon we had got  into more open country and beyond their power.
We had not so much to fear from  them during the day, but they would be very likely to rush us by night;  so the sooner we got away from their neighborhood the better.
We were able now to take a more leisurely view of the Indians whom we  had rescued.
We all awoke exhausted after the terrific emotions and scanty food of  yesterday.

We had hardly closed the  thornbush door of our zareba, clasped each others hands, and thrown  ourselves panting upon the ground beside our spring, when we heard a  patter of feet and then a gentle, plaintive crying from outside our  entrance.
We ran forward into the open to meet our friends, and pressed a loaded  rifle into the hands of each.
We slunk  through the bushes in silence until we came to the very edge of the  cliff, close to the old camp.
We filled in the time by opening one of our food tins and making sure  of our breakfast.
We were  rising from our brushwood hidingplace when suddenly I felt his grip  upon my arm.
We were all fascinated to see them take the dive,  even when we thought it would be our turn next on the springboard.
We listened intently, but nothing save the calling of the birds broke  the deep peace of the forest.
We have thought of that.
We have to bear in mind, remarked Summerlee, that there are many  prehistoric forms which have never come down to us.

We  were all sleeping round our dying fire when we were arousedor,  rather, I should say, shot out of our slumbersby a succession of the  most frightful cries and screams to which I have ever listened.
We should not be here if you hadnt, said I, with conviction.
We are  exceptionally well informed, Summerlee, as to the habits of the enraged  pterodactyl.
We staggered through the brushwood, and even as we reached the trees  the harpies were on us again.

We passed very slowly through the woods, partly because Lord Roxton  acted as scout before he would let us advance, and partly because at  every second step one or other of our professors would fall, with a cry  of wonder, before some flower or insect which presented him with a new  type.
We saw the shimmering slaty gleam of their skins  between the treetrunks, and their heads undulating high above the  brushwood.
We therefore blocked the entrance to our zareba by filling it up with  several thorny bushes, and left our camp with the stores entirely  surrounded by this protecting hedge.

We had the evidence of our own eyes that the place was  inhabited by some unknown creatures, and there was that of Maple  Whites sketchbook to show that more dreadful and more dangerous  monsters might still appear.
We want to have  a good look at our neighbors before we get on visitin terms.
We shifted our  position from among the tickladen bushes until we came to a small  clearing thickly surrounded by trees upon all sides.
We cannot do less than call it Ixodes Maloni.
We forbore to light a fire or to make  any unnecessary sound.
We supped and camped at the very edge of the cliff, quenching our  thirst with two bottles of Apollinaris which were in one of the cases.
We were still discussing it,  endeavoring to adjust our minds to these new conditions, when a  singular scene in the plain below arrested our attention.
We nearly killed you with a stone at the cave, he cried; but this is  better.
We were too astounded to speak.
We had each bandoliers of cartridges.
We all have our professions, and soldierin is mine.
We can at least all reach the summit, said he.

We were a disconsolate party, for nothing could have been more  minute than our investigation, and it was absolutely certain that there  was no single point where the most active human being could possibly  hope to scale the cliff.
We have shaken off some of that  horrible insect life which is the bane of tropical travel.

We could not ourselves see  whence the rock had come, but our halfbreed servants, who were still  at the opening of the cave, said that it had flown past them, and must  therefore have fallen from the summit.
We had gathered in a little group at the bottom of the chasm, some  forty feet beneath the mouth of the cave, when a huge rock rolled  suddenly downwardsand shot past us with tremendous force.
We were too excited to return to the camp, but must make our first  exploration at once.
We  ordered the camp to be pitched, however, and, leaving the Indians to  arrange it, we four, with the two halfbreeds, proceeded up the narrow  gorge.
We can only accept  his guidance and follow on to the westward.

We moved off in silence, and continued to coast round the line of  cliffs, which were as even and unbroken as some of those monstrous  Antarctic icefields which I have seen depicted as stretching from  horizon to horizon and towering high above the mastheads of the  exploring vessel.
We were passing along the edge  of this cover when my eye was caught by the gleam of something white  within it.

We traveled entirely by compass, and  once or twice there were differences of opinion between Challenger and  the two Indians, when, to quote the Professors indignant words, the  whole party agreed to trust the fallacious instincts of undeveloped  savages rather than the highest product of modern European culture.
We will  kill you if we can, said the men in the east.

We found that all our possessions fitted very easily into  the two canoes, and we divided our personnel, six in each, taking the  obvious precaution in the interests of peace of putting one Professor  into each canoe.
We have not, it is true,  ascended the plateau, but it lies before us, and even Professor  Summerlee is in a more chastened mood.
We should soon come upon rapids, he  explained, which would make its further use impossible.

We sprang to our feet  with a gasp of astonishment as Challenger, in a round, boyish strawhat  with a colored ribbonChallenger, with his hands in his jacketpockets  and his canvas shoes daintily pointing as he walkedappeared in the  open space before us.
We have only to return home and  report him as the brazen imposter that he is.
We looked at each other in a bewildered silence, which was broken by a  discordant burst of derisive laughter from Professor Summerlee.
We have seven more minutes, said he.
We are to be companionswhat?
We may  get a scoop, if we are lucky.
We had a little difference at first.
We know  equally that it must be a very difficult one, otherwise the creatures  would have come down and overrun the surrounding country.
We can only suppose that he must have made his way to the summit and  seen it there.
We progress, do we not?
We will now  leave the dead American and proceed with my narrative.
We reentered the room which we had left so tumultuously ten minutes  before.
We cant all be Stanleys and Burtons, said I; besides, we dont get  the chance,at least, I never had the chance.

We had been  friends, quite good friends; but never could I get beyond the same  comradeship which I might have established with one of my  fellowreporters upon the Gazette,perfectly frank, perfectly kindly,  and perfectly unsexual.
We  have it filed at the office.
We must all bow to you, and try to get a  favorable word, must we?
We did a  Catharinewheel together down the passage.
We went with a back  somersault down the front steps.
We shall have a coalition presently, he boomed, looking from his wife  to me and puffing out his enormous chest.
We know, therefore, that there is a way up.
We cant have this reign of terror, Mr.
We must bring the man to his bearings.
We could notor at least  we had not succeeded up to date in making organic life in our  laboratories out of inorganic materials.
We can start tomorrow.
We are sending home one of our local Indians who  is injured, and I am committing this letter to his charge, with  considerable doubts in my mind as to whether it will ever come to hand.
We will kill you if we can.
We will kill you if we  can, said the men in the north.
We drew them up, therefore, and concealed  them among the bushes, blazing a tree with our axes, so that we should  find them again.
We are, in truth, as far from any human aid as if we were in the moon.
We did indeed, but they were of a terrible and most unexpected nature.
We had proceeded some five more miles when again we saw a white arrow  upon the rocks.
We had had no  food for many hours, and were very weary with the stony and irregular  journey, but our nerves were too strung to allow us to halt.
We made our way backthe whole gorge was not more than a  quarter of a mile deepand then suddenly the quick eyes of Lord John  fell upon what we were seeking.
We withdrew hurriedly from the chasm, our minds full of this new  development and its bearing upon our plans.
We made a march that day which totaled some twoandtwenty miles,  without any change in our prospects.
We all sat in amazed silence round the fire, like the heroes  of Virgil when the Harpies came down upon them.
We can never get across, I gasped.
We are,  accordin to my ideas, invadin a new country, which may or may not be  chockfull of enemies of sorts.
We had turned away from the edge, and had penetrated about fifty yards  of close brushwood, when there came a frightful rending crash from  behind us.
We could only stand there staring in  amazement.
We had been natives of the world; now we were natives of the  plateau.
We realized that  Zambo spoke the truth, and that it would be impossible for him to keep  them.
We will advance.
We must never go so far that we cant get back to our base.
We then slowly and cautiously set  forth into the unknown, following the course of the little stream which  flowed from our spring, as it should always serve us as a guide on our  return.
We all stopped to examine that monstrous spoor.
We may have traveled two or three miles in all, keeping to the  right of the line of the stream, when we came upon a considerable  opening in the trees.

We were walking  slowly towards these rocks, among bushes which reached over our waists,  when we became aware of a strange low gabbling and whistling sound,  which filled the air with a constant clamor and appeared to come from  some spot immediately before us.
We saw him peep over them and give a  gesture of amazement.
We beat at them with the stocks of our guns, but there was nothing  solid or vulnerable to strike.
We kept to  our camp all day, therefore, Lord John busying himself, with such help  as we could give him, in raising the height and thickness of the thorny  walls which were our only defense.
We clapped our hands to our ears to shut out that nerveshaking appeal.
We shall know in the morning, said Lord John.

We have been privileged to overhear a prehistoric tragedy, the sort of  drama which occurred among the reeds upon the border of some Jurassic  lagoon, when the greater dragon pinned the lesser among the slime,  said Challenger, with more solemnity than I had ever heard in his  voice.
we all cried.
We cant  afford to take chances in a country like this.
We dont know  who or what may be near us.
We know roughly that this  plateau is not larger than an average English county.
We can only imagine, therefore, that the balance of  Nature is preserved by some check which limits the numbers of these  ferocious creatures.
We saw many small animals, such as porcupines, a scaly anteater, and a  wild pig, piebald in color and with long curved tusks.
We have spent two long days in exploration, said he, and we are no  wiser as to the actual geography of the place than when we started.
We heard a row, as if your foot had slipped.
We had seen several of the sort, the  runs of various wild beasts, during our expeditions.
We must move, and move quick!
We relied upon the fact that we could count  upon the good word of those whom we had rescued to ensure a warm  welcome from their fellows.
We fitted him up  with an empty beef tin and he is off.
We four white men walked in the  rear with rifles loaded and ready.
We were indeed a sorry crew, and I did  not wonder to see our Indian companions glance back at us occasionally  with horror and amazement on their faces.
We are assembled now and ready.
We seem to be drifting very far from the object of this expedition,  Lord John.
We have been privileged, he cried, strutting about like a gamecock,  to be present at one of the typical decisive battles of historythe  battles which have determined the fate of the world.
We also continually visited their caves, which  were most remarkable places, though whether made by man or by Nature we  have never been able to determine.
We were soon to discover that it was not  so, and that he was still there upon tolerance.
We had never  before seen them save at night,  and indeed they are nocturnal animals  save when disturbed in their lairs, as these had been.
We had little time to watch them, however, for in an instant they had  overtaken the fugitives and were making a dire slaughter among them.
We are also unable to construct any kind of bridge  which may take us back to the pinnacle from which we came.
We stood with bitter hearts staring at this unexpected obstacle.
We had not gone thirty yards before a great  black opening loomed in the wall.
We stared in amazement.
We hastened towards it.
We are through, boys!
We satisfied ourselves  that with the help of our rope we could find our way down, and then  returned, rejoicing, to our camp to make our preparations for the next  evening.
We had hoped that we should find upon  our return that no one was so dense as to dispute our joint  conclusions.
We bobbed and  grinned in front of each other.
We are getting our house ready, said  Gladys.
We have no secrets.
We are shipbuilders.
We were young; we  craved thrills, and God knows we got them that day; yet by comparison  with that through which I have since passed they were as tame as a  PunchandJudy show.
We were aboard an  American shipwhich, of course, was not armed.
We must grin and bear it, she replied after a  moment.
We were approaching the Uboat at half speed now, and I could almost  distinguish the features of the men upon her deck.
We  heard a loud explosion apparently directly above us; the craft trembled  to the shock which threw us all to the deck.
We cant  do it.
We ran steadily along upon the surface, making good  time.
We  worked upon the engine all that day and night and half the following  day.
We were  steaming along slowly upon the surface, my orders having been to  proceed at half speed until we could take an observation and determine  our position.
We still have the compass and the  sun, said Olson.
We kept steadily to our westward course, and as the U33 was one of the  fastest submersibles we had ever turned out, I knew that we must be  pretty close to the North American coast.
We kept to our westerly course for several hours when the lookouts cry  announced a sail.
We could not lie there in the middle of the  Atlantic and starve to death if there was any way out of it.

We had no opportunity for drill; but every man had been  posted as to his duties, and the German members of the crew understood  that it was obedience or death for them, as each was accompanied by a  man with a pistol.
We addressed  both to any British agent with the request that the owners of the  Balmen be reimbursed; but whether or not they were, I do not know.
We cruised for a long time, sinking many vessels, all but one by  gunfire, but we did not come across a German raider.
We had all the Germans we could take care of.
We threw his body overboard.
We didnt know what  course we had been holding, and there was no way of finding out, as we  could no longer trust the compass, not knowing what Benson had done to  it.
We all drank water together this  morning.
We  must find water on Caprona, or we must die.

We had not as yet really commenced to  suffer for lack of water; but I knew that it would not be long before  we did, and so at the first streak of dawn I moved in again and once  more took up the hopeless survey of the forbidding coast.
We must believe the other until we prove it  false.
We both scanned the water and the coastline.
We  came up to within twentyfive feet of the sheer wall, which loomed high  above us.
We were moving slowly up the river as the creature bore down upon us  with distended jaws.
We had not spoken for some  days, and we did not speak now; but she gave me a disdainful look,  which was quite as eloquent as words, and broke loose from my grasp.
We never  counted the girl on either side, I suppose because she was a girl,  though we knew well enough now that she was ours.
We had food enough, and with the water we were all  quite refreshed; but we missed fresh meat.
We had a pleasant meal, with only one  unfortunate occurrencewhen Olson suggested that possibly the creature  we were eating was the same one that ate the German.
We discussed the future and ventured opinions as to what lay before us;  but we could only theorize at best, for none of us knew.
We coasted up the shore of the lake in a northwesterly direction,  sounding all the time.

We are safe now in the matter of  food and water; we could provision the U33 for a long cruise; but we  are practically out of fuel, and without fuel we cannot hope to reach  the ocean, as only a submarine can pass through the barrier cliffs.
We both fired at once and had the satisfaction of seeing  the buck drop; then we ran forward to finish him with our knives.
We gathered up what was left of the red deer after skinning and  cleaning it, and set out upon our return journey toward the Uboat.

We ran for the better part of a mile without hearing anything more from  the direction of the harbor, and then I reduced the speed to a walk,  for the exercise was telling on us who had been cooped up for so long  in the confined interior of the U33.

We had been passing through a little  heavier timber than was usual to this part of the country, when we  suddenly emerged into an open space in the center of which was such a  band as might have caused the most courageous to pause.

We then retraced our steps for our meat being  convinced by our own experience that those aboard the U33 had been  able to frighten off this party with a single shellbut when we came  to where we had left the deer it had disappeared.

We felt that we had taught these wild apemen a lesson and that because  of it we would be safer in the futureat least safer from them; but we  decided not to abate our carefulness one whit, feeling that this new  world was filled with terrors still unknown to us; nor were we wrong.
We set the men at work  felling trees, selecting for the purpose jarrah, a hard,  weatherresisting timber which grew in profusion near by.
We have just finished it, the last  touches being put on today.
We have also  dried a large quantity of two varieties of cereal which grow wild a few  miles south of us.
We have had to  construct a second store house for the great quantity of this that we  have gathered.
We have settled down to  an acceptance of our fate, for all are convinced that none of us will  ever see the outer world again.
We had rhinocerossteaks for  supper.
We scaled the cliffs as far as we could; but near the top  they are absolutely perpendicular without any sufficient cleft or  protuberance to give hand or foothold.
We even had a  hope that we might see and attract the attention of a passing ship.
We are all becoming accustomed to adventure.
We suffered no casualties and there was no illness.
We worked with him for two days until he got things fairly  well started, and then we returned to Fort Dinosaur, as I feared that  Bradley might return and be worried by our absence.
We learned to know one another better in those  two brief hours than we had in all the months that had intervened since  we had been thrown together.
We cannot last a halfhour out here.
We may as well keep on in search of  another refuge.
We watched  them from our apartment, as Lys called it.
We will go together.
We are man and wife, and we  are content.

my.sentence: My clothes are worn to shreds.
My people are there.
My heart filled with rapture then, and it fills now as it has each of  the countless times I have recalled those dear words, as it shall fill  always until death has claimed me.
My men were all armed now with both rifles and pistols, each having  plenty of ammunition.

My theory is that  in a far distant era Caprona was a mighty mountainperhaps the worlds  mightiest mountainand that in some titanic eruption volcanic action  blew off the entire crest, blew thousands of feet of the mountain upward  and outward and onto the surrounding continent, leaving a great crater;  and then, possibly, the continent sank as ancient continents have been  known to do, leaving only the summit of Caprona above the sea.
My report filled everyone with theories and speculations, and with  renewed hope and determination.
My eyes were glued upon  the impenetrable mist astern, for there in the east I should see the  first glow of the rising sun that would assure me we were still upon  the right course.
My boche was bearing me toward the side of the submarine against which  the tug was still pounding.

My eyes were directed toward the point at which the  liner had disappeared when there came from the depths of the ocean the  muffled reverberation of an explosion, and almost simultaneously a  geyser of water in which were shattered lifeboats, human bodies, steam,  coal, oil, and the flotsam of a liners deck leaped high above the  surface of the seaa watery column momentarily marking the grave of  another ship in this greatest cemetery of the seas.
My eyes strained eagerly across the great plain in the hope of  seeing afar off the help for which we had prayed.
My senses  swam, but I still tore at the hand and forced it out from my chin.
My limbs ached, my  chest heaved, I felt that my throat would burst for want of air, and  yet with that horror behind me I ran and I ran and ran.
My useless fowlingpiece was in my hand.
My skin grew cold and my hair rose at  the thought.
My comrades were  delighted at my idea.
My comrades might be my masters on the rocks, but I knew  that I would be supreme among those branches.
My eyes chanced to  light upon the enormous gnarled trunk of the gingko tree which cast its  huge branches over us.
My cry of disgust had brought the two professors to my side.
My dear chap, said he, I really cannot allow it.
My time is of  value, and the same thing may be said, no doubt, in a lesser degree of  your own.
My directions for your instruction and guidance  are in this sealed envelope.
My paper will see to that.
My name is Edward Dunn Malone.
My companion waved his hand in contemptuous deprecation.
My instincts are all against a woman being too  frank and at her ease with me.
My character?

My scientific education having been somewhat  neglected, I was unable to follow the whole argument, but it was  evident that the English Professor had handled his subject in a very  aggressive fashion, and had thoroughly annoyed his Continental  colleagues.
My general conclusions you are good enough to approve, as I  understand?
My  mouth was full of  his beard, our arms were locked, our bodies  intertwined, and that infernal chair radiated its legs all round us.
My flippancy was all gone.
My small stock of knowledge was exhausted.
My wife has frequently remonstrated with me upon the subject, and yet  I fancy that any man of honor would feel the same.
My day was a busy one, and I had an early dinner at the Savage Club  with Tarp Henry, to whom I gave some account of my adventures.
My dear chap, things dont happen like that in real life.
My rooms are just over the road, in the Albany.
My trouser had slipped up, exposing a few inches of  my skin above my sock.
My dear Summerlee, I will tell you with great confidence exactly what  they will say in England, said Challenger.
My last  glance showed me the unconscious Summerlee, most futile of sentinels,  still nodding away like a queer mechanical toy in front of the  smouldering fire.
My attention was soon drawn away from these distant sights and brought  back to what was going on at my very feet.
My heart stood  still within me as it flashed across me that the beast, whatever it  was, must surely be after ME.
My only possible chance lay  in flight.
My heart sank at  that ominous stillness.
My God, what brutes!
My God!
My word!

My  own reading of the situation for what it is worth he inflated his  chest enormously and looked insolently around him at the wordsis  that evolution has advanced under the peculiar conditions of this  country up to the vertebrate stage, the old types surviving and living  on in company with the newer ones.
My three friends had all  lost their hats, and had now bound handkerchiefs round their heads,  their clothes hung in ribbons about them, and their unshaven grimy  faces were hardly to be recognized.
My answer is, that there was not one of us who was not working for this  end, but that our work had been in vain.
My home is in Santa Monica.
My  hand missed the girls by a fraction of an inch, and I saw her slip  into the sea; but scarce had she touched the water when I was in after  her.

My heart swelled with pride at the thought that  presently admiring British tars would be congratulating us upon our  notable capture; and just about then the merchant steamer must have  sighted us, for she veered suddenly toward the north, and a moment  later dense volumes of smoke issued from her funnels.
My hopes and my imagination ran riot  in the few yards I had to cover to reach that lonely grave and stoop  that I might read the rude characters scratched upon the simple  headstone.
My heart stood still at the thought, but mind  and muscle responded to the quick decision I was forced to make.

where.sentence: Where is the glamour of romance?
Where  the real sex feeling begins, timidity and distrust are its companions,  heritage from old wicked days when love and violence went often hand in  hand.
Where  have you been, young fellah?
Where  were all my nightly dreams of the open arms, the smiling face, the  words of praise for her man who had risked his life to humor her whim?

even.sentence: Even a superficial examination revealed the fact that  nothing had ever been attempted that might have improved the livability  of the cavern; nor, should I judge, had it ever been cleaned out.
Even poor Nobs appeared dejected as we quit the  compound and set out upon the wellmarked spoor of the abductor.
Even Professors might be misled by the desire for  notoriety.
Even as we looked a high whickering cry,  the call of some weird animal, rang clear out of the darkness.
Even in the  darkness as we lay upon the strand, we heard from time to time the  snort and plunge of the huge creatures who lived therein.
Even Challenger could give a few yards in a hundred to the  best of them, and you or I would be a perfect Shrubb.
Even now when I think of that nightmare the sweat breaks out upon my  brow.
Even if my comrades  should not have missed me, and should never know of my weakness, there  would still remain some intolerable selfshame in my own soul.
Even Challenger was affected by the consideration that his  enemies would never stand confuted if the confirmation of his  statements should never reach those who had doubted them.
Even the babies were as big as  elephants, while the two large ones were far beyond all creatures I  have ever seen.
Even the appearance of a very ordinary rock python does  not appear to justify such a liberty.
Even if they could send one, our fate  will in all human probability be decided long before it could arrive in  South America.
Even in these days  of Board schools    Well, I interrupted, any large South American animala tapir, for  example.

Even at that  moment of tension I found time for amazement at the discovery that he  was quite a short man, his head not higher than my shouldera stunted  Hercules whose tremendous vitality had all run to depth, breadth, and  brain.
Even in my short life I had learned as much  as thator had inherited it in that race memory which we call instinct.
Even at his worst I can usually  control him.
Even now I cant for the life  of me understand why you should have worked it in so extraordinary a  manner.
Even the hardy,  swaggering halfbreed seemed cowed.
Even as we looked, he sprang upon the back of the  fugitive and flung his arms round his neck.
Even with a modern rifle it would be all odds on the  monster.
Even now  I was on its huntingground.

Even Challenger was ready to admit that we should then have  done all for which we had come, and that our first duty from that time  onwards was to carry back to civilization the amazing discoveries we  had made.

Even the old chief met us with the same obstinate denial, and it was  only Maretas, the youngster whom we had saved, who looked wistfully at  us and told us by his gestures that he was grieved for our thwarted  wishes.
Even the names have been altered in our  accounts, and I am very sure that no one, from the most careful study  of them, could come within a thousand miles of our unknown land.
Even the unexpected fall of the Duke  of Durham into the orchestra, which occurred at this moment, could not  distract the petrified attention of the vast audience.
Even while the passengers were crowding the starboard rail and  scrambling into the few boats left to us, the submarine commenced  shelling the ship.

Even the grass upon the nearer bank was  unearthlylush and high it grew, and each blade bore upon its tip a  brilliant flowerviolet or yellow or carmine or bluemaking as  gorgeous a sward as human imagination might conceive.

gladys.sentence: Gladys would have told me to go.
Gladys was full of every womanly quality.
Gladys of the mystic lake, now to be  renamed the Central, for never shall she have immortality through me.

some.sentence: Some hideous member of the apeman  tribe had entered the fort and carried her off.

Some of them resembled the corpse we had found upon  the narrow beach against Capronas seawall, while others were of a  still lower type, more nearly resembling the apes, and yet others were  uncannily manlike, standing there erect, being less hairy and  possessing better shaped heads.
Some flowers and grasses and another leafy branch floated toward  us.
Some were torn and mangled; others lay  rolling quietly to the motion of the sea, their countenances composed  and peaceful; others were set in hideous lines of agony or horror.
Some attempts were also made to pull him down.
Some general indications will therefore  suffice.

Some day, when I have a better desk than a meattin and more helpful  tools than a worn stub of pencil and a last, tattered notebook, I will  write some fuller account of the Accala Indiansof our life amongst  them, and of the glimpses which we had of the strange conditions of  wondrous Maple White Land.
Some of them who had disappeared into the  jungle came back presently driving a young iguanodon before them.
Some distance down it I picked up my gun, and shortly afterwards struck  the brook which was my guide.
Some  fresh surprise was ever in store for us.
Some further remark  of Lord Roxtons about the danger only made me irritable.
Some day, perhaps, when  you have won your place in the world, we shall talk it over again.

CHAPTER XVI                      A Procession!
CHAPTER XIV                    Those Were the Real Conquests    We had imagined that our pursuers, the apemen, knew nothing of our  brushwood hidingplace, but we were soon to find out our mistake.

CHAPTER XIII                   A Sight which I shall Never Forget    Just as the sun was setting upon that melancholy night I saw the lonely  figure of the Indian upon the vast plain beneath me, and I watched him,  our one faint hope of salvation, until he disappeared in the rising  mists of evening which lay, rosetinted from the setting sun, between  the faroff river and me.

Nobs leaped about and barked furiously.
Nobs had come over and nosed his muzzle into her  lap, and she stroked his ugly face, and at last she leaned over and put  her cheek against his forehead.
Nobs braced himself with all four feet  to keep from slipping into the scuppers and looked up into my face with  a questioning whine.
Nobs rose with a low  growl.
Nobs and I had gained some little distance from the ship  when it rolled completely over and sank.
Nobs stood upon another and barked.
Nobs and I met with no sharks upon our return journey to the submarine.

fortunately.sentence: Fortunately the small boats presented a rather poor target,  which, combined with the bad marksmanship of the Germans preserved  their occupants from harm; and after a few minutes a blotch of smoke  appeared upon the eastern horizon and the Uboat submerged and  disappeared.

her.sentence: Her manner was so straightforward and honest that I could not bring  myself to believe in her duplicity; yetThinking to surprise her into  a betrayal of her guilt, I blurted out:  The chronometer and sextant  were both destroyed last night; there is a traitor among us.
Her face was  turned upward, held above the surface by her lifebelt, and was framed  in a floating mass of dark and waving hair.
Her bed had  been occupied, and her clothing lay where she had placed it the  previous night upon retiring; but Lys was gone.

ii.sentence: II I stammered, moving away and stumbling over the next thwart.

constantly.sentence: Constantly we  scanned the horizon for signs of smoke, venturing guesses as to our  chances of rescue; but darkness settled, and the black night enveloped  us without ever the sight of a speck upon the waters.

isnt.sentence: Isnt there something I can do?

nobbler.sentence: Nobbler came and lay down on the thwart beside me, his back against my  leg, and I sat staring in dumb misery at the girl, knowing in my heart  of hearts that she might die before morning came, for what with the  shock and exposure, she had already gone through enough to kill almost  any woman.

forgive.sentence: Forgive me, I managed to stammer.

hers.sentence: Hers went very wide at first, and then slowly comprehension  came to her, and she smiled.

shortly.sentence: Shortly after daylight we saw smoke apparently coming straight toward  us, and after a time we made out the squat lines of a tugone of those  fearless exponents of Englands supremacy of the sea that tows sailing  ships into French and English ports.

Shortly after we resumed our course upstream, we saw the mouth of  another and smaller river emptying into the main channel from the  souththat is, upon our right; and almost immediately after we came  upon a large island five or six miles in length; and at fifty miles  there was a still larger river than the last coming in from the  northwest, the course of the main stream having now changed to  northeast by southwest.
Shortly afterward Lys awoke, and for a moment she could not seem to  comprehend her situation.

willing.sentence: Willing hands dragged us to the deck, Nobs scrambling nimbly aboard  without assistance.

plying.sentence: Plying us both with questions they hustled her to the captains  cabin and me to the boilerroom.

americans.sentence: Americans have been building submarines for  all nations for many years.

tyke.sentence: Tyke er an  use er, was all he said.

evidently.sentence: Evidently her newfound philosophy  had tumbled about her ears, for she was seemingly taking herself  seriously.
Evidently they thought they were witnessing an exhibition  of poor seamanship, and they yelled their warnings to the tug to reduce  speed and throw the helm hard to port.
Evidently they were very low in the scale of humanity, but they were a  step upward from those I had previously seen in Caspak.

commanded.sentence: commanded  the tugcaptain, and instantly revolvers and rifles poured bullets upon  the deck of the submersible.

germans.sentence: Germans  were emerging from the open hatch to take part in the battle on deck.

kick.sentence: Kick and squirm as I would, I could  neither turn toward my antagonist nor free myself from his maniacal  grasp.

relentlessly.sentence: Relentlessly he was rushing me toward the side of the vessel  and death.

olsonwho.sentence: Olsonwho in spite of his name was Irish, and in spite of his not  being Scotch had been the tugs engineerwas standing with Bradley and  me.

yis,.sentence: Yis, he agreed, its a days worrk were after doin, but what  are we goin to be doin wid it now we got it?
Yis, sir, said Olson, behoind the cliffs!

bradley.sentence: Bradley did not return; nor  did we have any word from von Schoenvorts.
Bradley is  away again on another exploration expedition to the cliffs.
Bradley evidently  discovered something, or at least thought that he had.
Bradley happened to be looking toward the conningtower and  saw me.
Bradley was standing at my side.
Bradley had come on deck and was standing beside me.
Bradley now relieved Benson, for we  had arranged our shifts so that the latter and Olson now divided the  nights, while Bradley and I alternated with one another during the days.
Bradley passed the order down into the ship and a moment later the  guncrew clambered up the narrow ladder and at my direction trained  their piece upon the slowmoving Swede.
Bradley was now running from one to another of our men, and though some  of the Germans saw and heard him, they seemed too stunned for action.
Bradley swung the helm hard to starboard.
Bradley laugheda rather sorry laugh, though.

questioning.sentence: Questioning  the Germans, I found that all except the commander were willing to  resume their posts and aid in bringing the vessel into an English port.

take.sentence: Take  Tsas hole, which lies above you.
Take him away, I directed the two men who guarded him, and put him  in irons.
Take von Schoenvorts, for instance, I continued: he would doubtless  be glad to die and take us all with him, could he prevent in no other  way the falling of his vessel into enemy hands.

more.sentence: More rapidly now we closed the distance between ourselves and the  stranger, until I could plainly see the red ensign of the British  merchant marine.

lets.sentence: Lets try it again when this fellow has lost the scent, I urged.

later.sentence: Later we were fired upon by a destroyer, and two merchantmen turned and  fled at our approach.

Later I learned  that they had first overpowered Benson, who was asleep in his bunk, and  taken his pistol from him, and then had found it an easy matter to  disarm the cook and the remaining two Englishmen below.
Later in the evening Sota confided to me that she was soon to leave  the tribe.

guessing.sentence: Guessing at once what was  happening, I leaped for the hatch and slamming it closed above my head,  dropped to the centrale.

shed.sentence: Shed been in gassin wit the boche commander.

benson.sentence: Benson seen her in there las night, too, but he never said nothin  till I goes on watch tonight.
Benson gave me a knowing smile, as much as to  say:  Well, you and I know who did this.
Benson was in the tower, we were  bound for San Diego and all looked well.
Benson had relieved the guard early in the evening; there was no one to  watch himno one but Miss La Rue.

bensons.sentence: Bensons sorter slow in the head, an he  never puts two an two together till some one else has made four out of  it.

telling.sentence: Telling him never to fail to report to  me anything in the slightest out of the ordinary routine of the ship, I  dismissed him.

lys,.sentence: Lys, followed by Nobs, appeared as I entered the centrale.

men.sentence: Men are often glad to die for an idealan ideal of patriotism,  perhaps, I replied; and a willingness to martyr themselves includes a  willingness to sacrifice others, even those who love them.

women.sentence: Women are  much the same, except that they will go even further than most  menthey will sacrifice everything, even honor, for love.

seeing.sentence: Seeing an opening and an  advantage, I sought to follow it up.

look,.sentence: Look, captain, he said, and pointed south.

hurrying.sentence: Hurrying to the tower, I  looked at the compass.

either.sentence: Either the sun was rising in the south, or the  compass had been tampered with.

turning.sentence: Turning quickly, I climbed out upon the conningtower.
Turning toward Bradley, who was in the  conningtower, I snapped out: Gunservice on deck!

fire.sentence: Fire a shot across her bow,  I instructed the guncaptain.

accept.sentence: Accept it from me, it didnt take that Swede long to see the error of  his way and get the red and white pennant signifying I understand to  the masthead.

six.sentence: Six or seven miles farther, and the river widened considerably; before  us opened an expanse of water to the farther horizon, and then we  sailed out upon an inland sea so large that only a shoreline upon our  side was visible to us.
Six of us of the loyal crew had come on deck either to serve the gun or  board the Swede during our setto with her; and now, one by one, we  descended the ladder into the centrale.

below.sentence: Below these in  the scale of evolution came the Bolu, or clubmen, and then the Alus,  who had no weapons and no language.
Below all was  quietnot a man remained.

glancing.sentence: Glancing up, I saw that the tower was empty, and I lost no time in  clambering up, looking about me.

my,.sentence: My, I thought, what a wonderful targ I stopped even  thinking, so surprised and shocked was I by the boldness of my imagery.

ask.sentence: Ask Olson to step down  here, please, I requested; and dont let anyone see you ask him.

von.sentence: Von Schoenvorts had succeeded in refining the oil!
Von Schoenvorts had completed his  swaggerstick, and he and I were passing close to where the two worked.
Von Schoenvorts  was the worsthe was fairly frenzied with rage and chagrin, and he  came charging for me like a mad bull, and as he came he discharged his  pistol.
Von Schoenvorts had  recovered from his first surprise quickly and had turned toward the  main hatch to investigate.

olson.sentence: Olson and von Schoenvorts came up a minute later with their men; then  we all cautiously approached the still form upon the ground.
Olson was below, so that there were only nine of us against eight  Germans, for the man Bradley had struck still lay upon the deck.

Olson was looking up, and seeing what was poking about in the tower,  ran for an ax; nor did he hesitate a moment when he returned with one,  but sprang up the ladder and commenced chopping away at that hideous  face.
Olson ate until I thought he would burst.
Olson says  there is a geyser of oil there, and von Schoenvorts is making  preparations to refine it.

lys.sentence: Lys and I decided that it was a sort of  original religious conviction, as much a part of them as their instinct  for selfpreservationa primal acceptance of a hereafter and a holier  state.
Lys head had drooped to my breast,  and my arm was still about her.
Lys gave a little cry of joy and started toward  me, but Tsa grasped her arm and dragged her back.
Lys spent a great deal of time  talking to him and trying to draw him out; but for a long while she was  unsuccessful.
Lys stood with a heavy blanket wrapped around her slender figure, and  as I approached her, she half turned toward me to see who it was.
Lys was coldly polite to me and sweetly gracious to Bradley and Olson.
Lys came with us, and we took a number of things which  von Schoenvorts wanted for the purpose of erecting a crude refinery.
Lys shuddered, and I put my arm around her and drew her to me; and thus  we sat throughout the hot night.

late.sentence: Late in July, 1916, an item in the shipping news mentioned a  Swedish sailing vessel, Balmen, Rio de Janeiro to Barcelona, sunk by a  German raider sometime in June.

pardon.sentence: Pardon me, she said, but were I you, I should watch this man  Bensonespecially when he is in charge.

possibly,.sentence: Possibly, too, you will understand some  other things that have taken place aboard.

thinking.sentence: Thinking the thoughts of a lunatic or a dopefiend, I fell asleep; and  when I awoke, my hands and feet were securely tied and my weapons had  been taken from me.

Thinking to attract attention from inside the craft, I again ran down  the ladder and onto the small deck only to find that the steel covers  of the conningtower windows were shut, and then I leaned with my back  against the tower and cursed myself for a gullible idiot.

nowilay.sentence: NowIlay medowntosleep  That was all; Benson was dead.

cliffs,.sentence: Cliffs, seemingly rising  perpendicularly out of the sea, faded away into the mist upon either  hand as we approached.

caprona.sentence: Caprona has been  luring us upon her deadly rocks.
Caprona was  impregnablethat was the decision of all; yet we kept on.

straight.sentence: Straight from the oceans depths rose towering cliffs, shot  with brown and blues and greenswithered moss and lichen and the  verdigris of copper, and everywhere the rusty ocher of iron pyrites.

toward.sentence: Toward noon we discovered a beach, the first we had seen.

miss.sentence: Miss La Rue was very  quiet, though she replied graciously enough to whatever I had to say  that required reply.
Miss La Rue was on deck with  us.

sure,.sentence: Sure, you ought to carry a knoife.

this,.sentence: This, he  said, would account for its heat; but even as he spoke a bush, covered  thickly with leaves and flowers, bubbled to the surface and floated off  astern.

flowering.sentence: Flowering shrubs dont thrive in the subterranean caverns from which  geysers spring, suggested Bradley.

ye.sentence: Ye spoke a true word,  sirbehoind!

youd.sentence: Youd be after sailin into that blank pocket?

huge.sentence: Huge insects hummed and buzzed hither and thither.

mighty.sentence: Mighty  forms could be seen moving upon the ground in the thick forest, while  the bosom of the river wriggled with living things, and above flapped  the wings of gigantic creatures such as we are taught have been extinct  throughout countless ages.

shrieking.sentence: Shrieking and screaming, the German was dragged from the deck, and the  moment the reptile was clear of the boat, it dived beneath the surface  of the water with its terrified prey.

olsoni.sentence: Olsoni filled us all with a hitherto unfelt  admiration for him and all his kind.

olsons.sentence: Olsons to get all the steaks for himself.

gradually,.sentence: Gradually, we commenced to divest  ourselves of our clothing, retaining only sufficient for modesty; but  the sun was not hot.

olson,.sentence: Olson, Whitely, and Wilson each  wished to accompany me; but I told them that they were needed here,  since with Bradleys party still absent and the Germans gone it was  necessary that we conserve our force as far as might be possible.
Olson, von Schoenvorts, two  Englishmen and two Germans accompanied me, leaving ten to guard the  ship and the girl.
Olson, Whitely, Wilson, Miss La Rue,  and myself disembarked, while von Schoenvorts and his German crew  returned to refine the oil.
Olson, Whitely, Wilson, and I stood for a moment looking at one  another.

north.sentence: North of the clearing rose sandstone cliffs to a  height of some fifty to seventyfive feet, with tall trees growing at  their base and almost concealing them from our view.

motioning.sentence: Motioning for  silence and having the rest of the party lie down, I crept toward the  quarry, accompanied only by Whitely.

whitely.sentence: Whitely and Olson were up and dressed when we returned, and we all sat  down to a good breakfast.
Whitely looked at me, and I looked at  Whitely, and then we both looked back in the direction of the deer.

Whitely and I advanced very cautiously, and not having  the whole party with us, we fared better than on the journey out,  bagging two large antelope not a halfmile from the harbor; so with our  game and our prisoner we made a cheerful return to the boat, where we  found that all were safe.

wot.sentence: Wot sy we pot the bloomin bird, sir?

hi.sentence: Hi wouldnt sy that, sir, said Whitely; it sounds blasphemous.

hat.sentence: Hat the eart, siryes, sir, he replied, and raised his piece to his  shoulder.

nobs,.sentence: Nobs, by dint of much scrambling and one or two narrow escapes from  death, had managed to follow us up the cliff and was now curled between  me and the doorway, having devoured a piece of the dried meat, which he  seemed to relish immensely.
Nobs, though, was lightning by comparison with the slow thinking beast  and dodged his opponents thrust with ease.

because,.sentence: Because, said von Schoenvorts in his disagreeable way, the beast is  so large, and its nervous organization of so low a caliber, that it  took all this time for the intelligence of death to reach and be  impressed upon the minute brain.

drop.sentence: Drop that carcass, I directed the men carrying the  meat, and follow me!

puffing.sentence: Puffing and panting, we plodded  on until within about a mile of the harbor we came upon a sight that  brought us all up standing.

bradley,.sentence: Bradley, von Schoenvorts  and I, with Miss La Rues help, staked out the various buildings and  the outer wall.

he,.sentence: He,  being a Prussian and a gentleman, couldnt stoop to such menial labor  in the presence of his men, and I didnt see fit to ask it of him, as  the work was purely voluntary upon our part.

nor.sentence: Nor did he move until I said to him:  Plesser, you may  return to your quarters and dress your wound.

involuntarily,.sentence: Involuntarily, I laid my hand  upon hers where it rested on the rail.

ahm.sentence: Ahm taught  us a few things that have proved profitable and saved us much  ammunition, which it is useless to expend except for food or in the  last recourse of selfpreservation.
Ahm went out to hunt with us yesterday and was much impressed by the  ease with which our rifles brought down antelopes and deer.
Ahm had  spoken of it many times.

september.sentence: September 3, 1916:  Three months ago today the torpedo from the U33  started me from the peaceful deck of the American liner upon the  strange voyage which has ended here in Caspak.
September 7, 1916:  Much has happened since I last wrote.

ahms.sentence: Ahms repeated assertions that there  are human beings like ourselves in Caspak have roused the men to a keen  desire for exploration.

ahm,.sentence: Ahm, who is now free to go and come as he wishes, accompanied them.

game.sentence: Game was plentiful and we saw several  varieties which we had not before encountered in Caspak.

passed.sentence: Passed through dense forests close to the base of the cliffs.

saw.sentence: Saw  manlike creatures and a low order of ape in one band, and some of the  men swore that there was a white man among them.

indisputable.sentence: Indisputable evidence of this is on  the face of the cliffs.

plesser.sentence: Plesser said they had been attacked  by wild men and had exhausted a great deal of ammunition.

low.sentence: Low and sweet and tender came the answer:  I love you beyond all  conception.

wilson,.sentence: Wilson, who was acting as cook, was up and  astir at his duties in the cookhouse.

afterward.sentence: Afterward I shot the beast,  and Nobs had a feast while I dressed, for he had become quite a  rawmeat eater during our numerous hunting expeditions, upon which we  always gave him a portion of the kill.

crushing.sentence: Crushing the bit of fabric to my lips, I pressed on even more  rapidly than before, because I now knew that I was upon the right trail  and that up to this point at least, Lys still had lived.

cautiously.sentence: Cautiously I approached the flank of the cliffs, where they terminated  in an abrupt escarpment as though some all powerful hand had broken off  a great section of rock and set it upon the surface of the earth.

cautioning.sentence: Cautioning Nobs to silence, and he  had learned many lessons in the value of obedience since we had entered  Caspak, I slunk forward, taking advantage of whatever cover I could  find, until from behind a bush I could distinctly see the creatures  assembled by the fire.

however.sentence: However I caught the gist of what he  was sayingwhich in effect was that he had found and captured this  Galu, that she was his and that he defied anyone to question his right  of possession.

o.sentence: O God, she cried, give me the strength to  endure, for his sake!

selecting.sentence: Selecting a  burning branch for each of us, we advanced toward the cliffs, where we  were met by angry threats.

rough.sentence: Rough  and narrow ledges formed by nature gave access to the upper caves.

pieces.sentence: Pieces of the roof had fallen at some longdistant date,  as was evidenced by the depth of the filth and rubble in which they  were embedded.

neither.sentence: Neither men nor women wore  any sort of clothing or ornaments, and they all seemed to be about of  an age; nor were there any babies or children among them.

tippet.sentence: Tippet lying here in this gloomy wood!

californians,.sentence: Californians, as a  rule, are familiar with jujutsu, and I especially had made a study of  it for several years, both at school and in the gym of the Los Angeles  Athletic Club, while recently I had had, in my employ, a Jap who was a  wonder at the art.

sota.sentence: Sota said that she would enter  alone; I must not be seen if I did not intend to remain, as it was  forbidden that one should return and live after having advanced this  far.
Sota will go with you back to the Galus.

Sota had given me a  suggestion; but the resulting idea was so weird that I could scarce  even entertain it; yet it coincided with Ahms expressed hope, with the  various steps in evolution I had noted in the several tribes I had  encountered and with the range of type represented in each tribe.
Sota soon to be Krolu, she confided in a low whisper.
Sota gave me a grateful look; but Tojo  and the balance of his women were sullen and ominous.

possibly.sentence: Possibly in the outer world the answer to it is locked in the bosom of  the Sphinx.

death,.sentence: Death, I may remark here, had, however, lost much of  his terror for me.

ata,.sentence: Ata, explained Sota, when I  questioned her as to the purpose of this matutinal rite; but that was  later.

together.sentence: Together we will go to the Krolu,  and after that the Galus.

strewn.sentence: Strewn along the ground were a score of mute and horrible suggestions  of what had taken place during my absencebones picked clean of flesh,  the bones of manlike creatures, the bones of many of the tribe of  Stolu; nor in any cave was there sign of life.

closely.sentence: Closely I examined the ghastly remains fearful each instant that I  should find the dainty skull that would shatter my happiness for life;  but though I searched diligently, picking up every one of the  twentyodd skulls, I found none that was the skull of a creature but  slightly removed from the ape.

near.sentence: Near the summit I came  upon a huge cavern.

luck.sentence: Luck and only luck it must have been which had permitted that  first shot to lay low one of the savage creatures, for even such a  heavy weapon as my pistol is entirely inadequate against even the  lesser carnivora of Caspak.

kho.sentence: Kho voiced a single horrid scream, stiffened  spasmodically and sank to the earth.
Kho closed and sought my jugular with his teeth.

fate.sentence: Fate was kind to us, Bowen.
